description.narrative:
Enhanced Integrated Framework (EIF) är ett program-baserat partnerskap som inkluderar de minst utvecklade länder (MUL), givare och internationella organisationer. Målet är att stödja MUL att vara mer aktiva aktörer inom det globala handelssystemet genom att hjälpa dem att minska deras hinder inom handelssektorn. På detta sätt arbetar EIF programmet mot ett övergripande mål för att främja ekonomisk tillväxt och hållbar utveckling. I dagsläget består EIF av 23 givare, 6 multilaterala organisationer (IMF, ITC, WTO, UNCTAD, UNDP, World Bank), 2 observatörer (UNIDO och UNWTO) och 51 länder (48 MUL och 3 länder som nyligen lämnade MUL kategorin).
Sida har gett stöd till EIF sedan 2009. Stödet har uppgått till 120 MSEK för implementering av EIF fas 1 som pågår fram tills 2017. Den föreslagna insatsen innebär att stödja EIF:s implementering av fas 2 med 100 MSEK under åren 2017-2021. Hela tidsperioden av EIF fas 2 omfattar åren 2016-2022 och insatsens totala indikativa budget ligger på 274-320 MUSD.
EIF:s syfte är oförändrat i fas 2 och syftar till att stödja MUL att: (1) integrera handel i nationella utvecklingsstrategier, (2) upprätta de strukturer som krävs för att samordna leveransen av handelsrelaterat tekniskt bistånd, och (3) bygga upp handelskapacitet, vilket även omfattar att ta itu med kritiska begränsningar på utbudssidan.
Fokus inom EIF är kapacitetsuppbyggnad inom handelsfrågor av MUL och framtagande av behovsanalyser, så kallade Diagnostic Trade Integration Studies (DTIS). Därefter tar man fram landspecifika åtgärdsmatriser i syfte att kunna identifiera aktörer och finansiärer som kan genomföra insatserna. I vissa fall implementeras och finansieras prioriterade åtgärder direkt inom ramen för EIF. Exempel på sådana prioriterade åtgärder från fas 1 är "High Value Silk" projektet som syftar till att öka konkurrenskraften hos den kambodjanska silke sektorn för att skapa arbetstillfällen särskilt för kvinnor, stöd för anslutning till WTO och kapacitetsuppbyggnad för handelsinstitutioner, regeringstjänstemän osv. Vidare syftar EIF programmet till att stärka givarnas stöd till landets egen handelsagenda. MUL kan använda EIF som en mekanism för att samordna givarstödet och tillför mer resurser inom deras handelsagenda, medan givarna kan ansluta sig till EIF som en mekanism för att leverera på deras åtaganden inom handelsfrågan. EIF:s aktiviteter finansieras genom en multi-donor trust fund.
EIF:s globala förvaltningsstruktur består av EIF styrkommittén, EIF styrelsen, EIF sekretariatet och en fondförvaltare. EIF:s styrkommitté fungerar som ett övergripande ledningsorgan, medan EIF:s styrelse är det beslutande organet för EIF-programmet och ger strategisk tillsyn. Styrelsen består av en representant från varje multilateral organisation (IMF, ITC, WTO, UNCTAD, UNDP, World Bank), tre representanter från de minst utvecklade länderna och tre representanter från givargruppen. EIF:s sekretariat är den genomförandepartner/operativa förvaltaren av EIF-programmet och är en del av WTO:s huvudkontor i Geneve, Schweiz. UNOPS regionala kontor i Geneve fungerar som fond/finansiell förvaltare för EIF fas 2 och är Sidas avtalspartner.
På landnivå leder en nationell EIF fokalpunkt själva EIF processen i landet, en EIF donor facilitator arbetar tillsammans med EIF fokalpunkten för att underlätta givarsamordningen och EIF:s nationella styrkommitté är ett forum för beslutsfattande och samordning mellan statliga parter inom handel, den privata sektorn, det civila samhället och givarna i det specifika landet.

The Enhanced Integrated Framework (EIF) is a program-based global partnership involving the Least Developed Countries (LDCs), donors and international organizations, to support LDCs to be more active players in the global trading system by helping them tackle obstacles to trade. In this way, the program works towards a wider goal of promoting economic growth and sustainable development. The EIF consists of 23 donors, 6 multilateral organizations (IMF, ITC, WTO, UNCTAD, UNDP, World Bank), two observers (UNIDO and UNWTO) and 51 countries (48 LDCs and the three countries that recently graduated from the LDC category).
Since 2009 Sida has supported the EIF with 120 MSEK for the implementation of phase 1 that lasts until 2017. Sida is now planning to support EIFs implementation of phase 2 with 100 MSEK over the period 2017-2021. The total of EIFs phase 2 covers the time period of 2016-2022. The intervention’s estimated total budget is 274-320 million USD.
The EIF's purpose remains unchanged in phase 2 and aims at supporting LDCs' own drive to: (1) mainstream trade into national development strategies, (2) set up structures needed to coordinate the delivery of trade-related technical assistance, and (3) build capacity to trade, which also includes addressing critical supply-side constraints.
The focus of the EIF is to build capacity within trade in LDCs and to carry out so-called Diagnostic Trade Integration Studies (DTIS) to understand the traderelated restrictions a country is facing. A country-specific action matrix is then formulated to be able to identify actors and financiers who can implement these actions. In some cases, priority actions are implemented and directly funded within the EIF program. Illustrative examples of such priority actions from phase 1 are for example the High Value Silk Project aimed at increasing the competitiveness of the Cambodian silk sector to create jobs particularly for women, assistance for WTO accession and capacity building activities for key trade support institutions, government officials etc. Furthermore, the EIF aims to strengthen donors' support to a country's trade agenda. LCDs can use the EIF as a vehicle to assist in coordinating donor support and to lever more resources within trade, whereas donors can sign up to the EIF as a vehicle to deliver on their commitments concerning trade. EIF activities are financed through a multi-donor trust fund.
The global EIF management structure consists of an EIF Steering Committee, the EIF Board, the EIF Executive Secretariat and a Trust Fund Manager. The EIF Steering Committee serves as the overall governing body of the EIF whereas the EIF board is the key decision-making body for the EIF program and provides strategic oversight. It is composed of one representative each from the six EIF partner agencies and by three representatives each of LDCs and donors. The EIF Excecutive Secretariat is Sida's implementing partner as well as the operational manager of the EIF program and is housed at WTO headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland. The UNOPS regional office in Geneva acts as trust fund/financial manager for EIF phase 2 and is Sida's agreement partner.
On the country level a national EIF focal point leads the EIF process in-country, a EIF donor facilitator works with the EIF focal point to facilitate donor coordination and the EIF National Steering Committee is a senior-level forum for decision-making and coordination among government partners on trade, the private sector, civil society and the donor community of the specific country.

Objectives of the intervention
The intended outcome of the EIF is to support the LDCs to use trade as a route to poverty reduction and sustainable development by enabling them to be more active players in, and beneficiaries of, the global trading system through mainstreaming trade. By the end of the intervention, the EIF has created a strong, sustainable and effective results-oriented partnership among all EIF stakeholders and provided a framework for trade capacity-building. Moreover, the EIF has provided support in the design and implementation of trade policy, alongside the necessary regulatory reform so that EIF countries own a trade agenda conducive to sustainable pro-poor growth as well as EIF countries have increased their presence in international markets.

participating-org.narrative: UNOPS/United Nations Office for Project Services

tag.narrative: 17.10 - Främja ett universellt, regelbaserat, öppet, icke-diskriminerande och rättvist multilateralt handelssystem inom ramen för Världshandelsorganisationen, inklusive genom att slutföra förhandlingarna enligt utvecklingsagendan från Doha.

17.10 - Promote a universal, rules-based, open, non-discriminatory and equitable multilateral trading system under the World Trade Organization, including through the conclusion of negotiations under its Doha Development Agenda.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.

description.narrative:
Background
Despite COVID 19 and other challenges persisting in 2021, least developed country (LDC) exports increased by an estimated 22% for the year. This maintains the share of the LDCs in global non-oil exports at 1% of the global total, though sustainably up from 0.5% in 2010. There has been continued and increasing commitment by the LDCs themselves to take a lead role in improving their economic situation, working handin-hand with EIF partners to build institutional and productive capacities, thereby contributing to strengthening their standing in the global trade market and their resilience to national and global shocks and challenges.
The EIF Agencies remain a central pillar for technical assistance to the LDCs (with 20% of all projects implemented directly, and more where EIF Agencies provide specialist services to projects). In total, 75 partners supported EIF Countries globally, including women entrepreneurs, micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprise (MSME) associations and regional development banks. This is aligned with the goal of EIF Phase Two, as well as the global recognition of the importance of cross-sectoral and crossthematic partnerships for effective sustainable development and trade.
The case for enhanced integration of the LDCs into global and regional trade markets continues to gain attention. Over 2021, the EIF's communication and advocacy efforts showed an increase of more than 116,500 new website users. EIF Country partners engaged in more than 88 meetings at the ministerial and expert level, again showcasing the interest, importance, and effectiveness of bringing country expertise and examples into the global policy dialogue. Learning and accountability were strengthened through a participatory programme evaluation.
Hereunder are some examples of concrete results achieved by 2021. The results are illustrated by the major components of the EIF programme.
A) Improved trade environment for inclusive and sustainable growth
1) 15 new trade and investment regulations adopted (59 in total), including the revision of the Investment Code in Comoros and the Decree on Cross-Border Trade in Equatorial Guinea. 2) 6 new trade- and investmentrelated policies with support from the EIF (52 in total), such as the Trade Policy Document in Guinea and an Intellectual Property policy in Rwanda.
3) 2 additional countries with government-donor dialogue mechanisms (45 in total), with the EIF playing a lead role in the coordination of project support towards Timor-Leste's accession to the WTO.
4) 1 country (Vanuatu) now leading regional indicators for digital and sustainable trade facilitation
B) Increased exports and access to international markets for the LDCs
1) 52 new international market transactions facilitated through EIF support (211 in total), such as dried fruit from Benin to Switzerland, Coffee from the Central African Republic to Nigeria, Cassava from the Solomon Islands to Australia, and honey from Zambia to Norway. USD
2) 210 Millions USD in new exports with contributions from EIF interventions (USD 680 million in total), including products such as cashew nuts from Togo and shea butter from Burkina Faso.
3) 60% of beneficiaries from EIF productive capacity-building projects are women (up from 56% in 2020), with women-centric projects being implemented in countries such as Bangladesh, Bhutan, Haiti, South Sudan, TimorLeste and Uganda.
Around 4,500 new jobs have been created with contributions from EIF projects (36,000 in total), such as horticulture in Lesotho or ecotourism in Comoros.
Sida has contributed in the strengthening of the EIF reporting and monitoring system through a call off agreement which has led to a marked improvement in the EIF capacity in monitoring and evaluating its support to LDCs.
The results achieved by the EIF are in in line with Sida's objectives in the area of trade. The EIF has contributed at both normative and operational levels. It has constributed to institutional strengthening in a number of LDCs.
The EIF programme, phase 2, is planned to be finalised by end of 2024. Sida's last disbursement of 15 MSEK scheduled for 2022 has been postponed to 2023. This postponement will not affect the programme as there are enough cash in UNOPS account which will be carried over to 2023. All the resources are now being used to complete all the ongoing projects, including reporting and evaluation. It is assessed that the objectives of the EIF programme will be met. Important to note that Sida has contributed with additional consultancy support to the EIF in order to strengthen the its RBM system.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
